title: The Vineyard Song and Woes
shortSummary: Isaiah chapter 5 presents a prophetic allegory of Israel as a vineyard that, despite God's care, produces only wild grapes, symbolizing Israel's failure to live righteously. The chapter pronounces a series of woes against various sins and announces God's impending judgment on His people for their rebellion and injustice.
timeline: c. 740-700 BC - Isaiah's prophetic ministry during the reigns of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah in Judah

keyCharacters.name: The Wellbeloved
keyCharacters.description: God, depicted as the owner of the vineyard who lovingly cultivates Israel but is disappointed by its fruit.

keyCharacters.name: Inhabitants of Jerusalem and Men of Judah
keyCharacters.description: The people of Judah and Jerusalem who are called to judge between God and His vineyard, representing Israel's leaders and citizens.

definitions.definition: A cultivated plot of land for growing grapes, used metaphorically here to represent the nation of Israel.
Grapes that are sour or worthless, symbolizing Israel's sinful and unfruitful behavior despite God's care.
An expression of judgment or lamentation pronounced against sinners or those who act unjustly.
Ancient Hebrew units of measure; a bath is a liquid measure and a homer is a dry measure, indicating poor agricultural yield.

outline.heading: The Song of the Vineyard
outline.description: God sings a lament over His vineyard, Israel, which He carefully prepared but which produced only wild grapes, symbolizing Israel's failure to produce righteousness and justice.

outline.heading: Judgment on Land Grabbers and Social Injustice
outline.description: A woe is pronounced against those who greedily accumulate land, resulting in desolation and poor productivity, highlighting social injustice.

outline.heading: Woes on Drunkenness and Indifference to God
outline.description: God condemns those who indulge in excessive drinking and revelry, ignoring His works, leading to captivity and humiliation.

outline.heading: Woes on Moral and Judicial Corruption
outline.description: A series of woes denounce those who persist in sin, invert moral values, pride themselves on their own wisdom, abuse alcohol, and pervert justice for gain.

outline.heading: The Lord’s Judgment and the Coming Invasion
outline.description: Because of Israel's rejection of God's law, His anger results in judgment through a swift and unstoppable invasion, bringing darkness and sorrow.

application: Examine your life for areas where God’s care has been met with unfruitfulness and repent to bear good spiritual fruit.
Avoid greed and selfishness that harm others, practicing generosity and justice as God commands.
Reject moral relativism by upholding biblical truth and righteousness in all areas of life.
Trust in God's sovereign judgment and seek to live in holiness and obedience to Him daily.

keyVerses.text: For the vineyard of the LORD of hosts is the house of Israel, and the men of Judah his pleasant plant: and he looked for judgment, but behold oppression; for righteousness, but behold a cry.
keyVerses.significance: This verse clearly identifies Israel as God's vineyard and highlights His expectation of justice and righteousness, contrasting with the people's failure.

keyVerses.text: Woe unto them that call evil good, and good evil; that put darkness for light, and light for darkness; that put bitter for sweet, and sweet for bitter!
keyVerses.significance: A powerful condemnation of moral inversion, warning against rejecting God's standards and embracing falsehood.

keyVerses.text: Therefore as the fire devoureth the stubble, and the flame consumeth the chaff, so their root shall be as rottenness, and their blossom shall go up as dust: because they have cast away the law of the LORD of hosts, and despised the word of the Holy One of Israel.
keyVerses.significance: This verse explains the cause and effect of Israel’s judgment—rejecting God's law leads to total destruction.

keyVerses.text: Therefore is the anger of the LORD kindled against his people, and he hath stretched forth his hand against them, and hath smitten them: and the hills did tremble, and their carcases were torn in the midst of the streets. For all this his anger is not turned away, but his hand is stretched out still.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes God's persistent judgment upon His people despite their suffering, underscoring the seriousness of rebellion.
